presentation.title: Balancing Speed and Safety
presentation.toc: Speeding up IT and business development without sacrificing stability and safety is one of the major challenges faced by many organizations today. The challenge increases with the size of the organization, the requirements for safety, and the rate of change of the environment. Balancing speed and safety must be done in a way that allows the organization to change in flexible ways. This requires systemic thinking and an organizational setup to manage this system in ways that allow quick changes and allow for monitoring and analysis. The ultimate objective is that organizational change becomes a process rather than a goal.

ul.li: Dee Hock, Birth of the Chaordic Age, Berrett-Koehler Publishers, January 2000
Traditional enterprise IT approaches favor integration
Integration aims at building one system that contains all essential parts
Integration provides optimization potential
Integration promises a destination instead of a journey
Integration cost/benefit analysis depends on how much change is required
Integrated systems tend to win as long as the future is (roughly) as predicted
Integrated systems can be costly if adaptation needs necessitate big changes
Ecosystems trade flexibility over integration optimization
Ecosystems tend to do worse as long as conditions remain mostly stable
Ecosystems tend to outperform/outlive integrated systems in light of bigger changes

presentation.title: Service Landscaping with a Purpose
presentation.toc: Managing the increasingly rapidly changing landscapes of IT services is a challenging task because of landscape size, rate of change, and heterogeneity. Organizations are forced to manage the increasing decentralization and diversity of this landscape to allow service discovery, and to understand the status quo as well as the constant evolution of the service ecosystem. Balancing the static beauty of a tidy landscape versus the dynamic nature of an increasingly quickly developing service ecosystem is one of many challenges large organizations are facing today.
